And add the TodoController APIs to your router. The Todos API has a URI prefix of “todos”.
Before we start adding routes, we going to use the
to separate our storage concerns from our API. With this we should be able to create an API and test it without worrying about Database setup.

protocol that defines all the methods to manage todos: (get, list, create, update, delete and deleteAll).
Create a concrete implementation of
protocol that saves everything to memory. We use an actor because multiple tasks could be accessing the repository at the same time.
Return to TodoController.swift
And add a generic repository member variable conforming to
to be used by the
routes.
Go to Todos.swift
And add the repository parameter to the TodoController initializer.
Return to TodoController.swift. We can now start adding our API.
Our first entrypoint is to return a Todo given an id in the URI. We extract the id from the URI, attempt to convert it to a UUID and then call the repository method
and return the result. The result is then converted to a response using the response encoder (JSONEncoder by default) attached to the context.
This entrypoint has a few other features. If it fails to convert the id to a UUID then it throws an

. This is an error that can be converted by the server to a valid HTTP response. If the server receives an error it cannot convert to an HTTP response it will return a 500 (Internal Server Error) HTTP error to the client.
If the entrypoint returns nil because it could not find a route this will automatically return a 204 (No Content) HTTP response to the client.

Our second entrypoint is to create a Todo. We have added a struct to decode from the request. In a similar way the get entrypoint response uses JSONEncoder to generate its response, this uses the JSONDecoder attached to the context. We then call the repository
method and return the result.
Returning an object and not a raw Response, in general sets the response status to 200 (OK). In this situation we want to return a 201 (Created) status. We can do this by returning an
which can be used to edit the status code and headers of a generated response.
We now have an API we can test. Lets use curl to create a Todo. If we include the command line parameter
we get the full HTTP response and that the status code is 201 (Created).
Then use curl to access the URL that was in the returned json from the previous curl call.
Cool it works!
Continuing with adding our API entrypoints
This is the entrypoint that lists all of the todos that have been created. Because Todo conforms to ResponseEncodable, Array<Todo> automatically conforms to ResponseEncodable as well.
This is the entrypoint that updates a todo. It extracts the todo id from the URI, decodes the UpdateRequest from the request and then calls the repository
function.
This is the entrypoint that deletes a todo. It extracts the todo id from the URI and calls the repository
function.
The final entrypoint is the one that deletes all todos. It simply calls the repository
function, as it doesn’t need to extract any information from the request.
Create a controller type that will hold the Todos API
Lets test the full API. First we are going to create two todos
When we query the URL returned by the first curl request we should get the first Todo added.
If we update the second Todo and set it to completed …
when we list all the tests you will see it is now flagged as completed
If we delete a Todo …
when we try to get it again a 204 (No Content) response is returned, as it no longer exists.
If we delete all of the Todos …
when we list the Todos, the list is empty.
This is not exactly a thorough way to test your application. It is error prone and cumbersome. Move onto the next chapter to discover how you can make this process more streamlined.
Use curl to ensure your API is working as expected.
